answers.answer: HI...I am so sorry ur DD is going thru this on top of being bullied by a teacher...I mean what in the world ...ugh...neway, please know that yes, stress can affect her motility issue as well as the acid.Modifying her diet and lifestyle can help with this as well as new interests...lying in bed can compound it as she is  dwelling on it.....Many  of the meds for gerd can take a while to show ne benefits....And it is possible with gerd meds to not absorb the vitamins and minerals from the natural source as well as from supplements, so do be susre she takes vitamins at a diff time to allow this.I take my gerd meds in the AM and my supplements at night b4 bed.One last thing on meds...if after a few weeks teh meds do not seem to help, ask about another med as not all meds work for everyone.Chewing gum, helps with a natural secretion of acids to help break down the excess....There r more tips in the Health Pageshttp://www.medhelp.org/health_pages/list?cid=236"selma"

question: My daughter is 13 years old.  She has for weeks if not months had increasing symptoms.  They were, and are:  nausea, "chest pain", severe stomach pains up high, coughing, lower back pain, some times pain in the side of the neck, feeling full soon after starting to eat, hungry often, headaches, and in general feeling awful.  Any regurgitation is less than any of the other symptoms. She had an endoscopy and was diagnosed with GERD and gastritis.  The specialist said that her stomach was inflamed and so was her esopha. where it meets the stomach.  She tested negative for H-Pylori.  At night, she will have joint aches and also is experiencing increasing frequency of a sore throat.  She has been on Tagamet [prescription strength], and is on non-containing NSAID pain relievers that are prescription strength.  The specialist put her on Aciphex last week, but it is not even making a dent in how she feels.  In addition, the foods are moving through her 'system' incredibly slow, and she is in pain when she uses the restroom.  The gastro.specialist is now saying he wants to test her for anemia [due to dizziness], not from bleeding but because he believes that her slow 'system' could be causing a B12 deficiency.  He is also wanting to check her for Diabetes 1, as he says that it can also cause a slow 'system' which could in return be why she is having gastritis and GERD.  Last, but not least, she had a terrible school year and I found out that she had not been eating at lunch.  She experiencing fainting spells at school, which now has decreased.  We believe that she was under so much stress from being bullied by a teacher and kids, and we wonder if this could be the cause of all of this.  Stress, I read, can cause an increase of acid production, and if it goes on for months then it can cause all the other things as well.  At the end of the day, the Aciphex is not helping, she is miserable, and I want to know if there are any medications that can kill the pain in her stomach.  And, what do you think I should be looking for beyond what the doctor is telling us? Could this be an autoimmune disease, such as Pernicious Anemia? Her quality of life is beyond ridiculous - she lives in her bed and gets out only on occasion, and we have stressed to the doctor how terrible she feels.Thank you.
title: 13 year old daughter not getting better with GERD and GASTRITIS
